So much* then, for the basic facts about the life of Italy’s new
prime minister. They have been embellished since he took office by
anecdotes and legends which inevitably crop up around a successful
politician*
Those of you who have been accosted by black market money changers
in Borne might appreciate this one; Pella was approached in the Plassa
Colonna one morning by ono of these traders, who offered to sell him a
hundred American dollars.
And the Italian minister of treasury and budget repliedi *Thank
you, no** Then he smiled and added, to the black marketeer! "You see,
X also sell dollars.*
To demonstrate Pella’s shrewdness in fending off delicate questions
they tell of a Journalist who recently asked the prime minister bluntly:
*Do you think it is possible that new elections will be held shortly?*
And Pella replied: *Certalnly I consider it possible — if necessary.*
An Italian political writer described Pella’s ability in
parliamentary debate in these words: *His dialectic is rather like
fencing: closed guard, elegant feints, lightning paste and riposte
that draw applause from a hostile Assembly and a smile from the Hon*
decchia (meaning Communist leader Pietro decehia).*
But another Journalist adds that Pella, while a skillful debater,
’’does not like to exasperate his adversaries.* He Invariably retains
his amiability*
